The other is for a positive reason: for an economic or system life consideration, where the controller is purposefully suspended from time to time. In [3], based on the average dwell time method, controller failure time analysis problem was studied, and exponential stability conditions were obtained by restricting the unavailability rate of the controller and the average time interval between controller failures. Subsequently, this result was extended to L 2 gain case in [4] and the case of dynamical output feedback in [5], respectively.

In almost all engineering control systems, delays are frequently encountered, which affect the performance of the system adversely, including causing instability [9]- [13]. It is obviously important to establish under what conditions the system is still exponentially stable subject to controller failure and the time varying-delay. To the best of the authors' knowledge, there have been few publications relating to this topic. Although [14] considers the controller failure for a kind of discrete system with constant delay in the control input, the system can be turned into an augmented system without delay, and the method is not applicable to time-varying delay systems. To deal with controller failure for time-varying delay systems, then there are two main issues to be addressed. One is the system model description; the other is the exponential stability analysis for the developed new model, since controller failure and time-varying delay often lead to the instability of the system. In this paper, it is assumed that the failure of the controller means the complete breakdown of the controller within a certain time interval and this will introduce an unstable subsystem. To keep the system exponentially stable with a certain decay rate, we need to investigate the degree of failure permissibility. To address this, the concept of controller failure frequency is introduced in this paper. The normal delay system with controller failure is first turned to a class of switched delay systems. Then, two lemmas reflecting the change property of Lyapunov functional candidates are developed, for normal delay systems without switching. Further to this, inspired by the switching method and based on a piecewise Lyapunov functional method, we develop exponential stability criterion for the considered system under the condition of controller failure frequency and unavailability rate. An example relating to packet dropout in networked control systems (NCSs) is given to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces model description and preliminaries; Section III gives two lemmas and the main result in this paper; an example on NCSs is given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in Section IV; some conclusions are drawn in Section V.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper has considered the analysis of controller failure for a class of time-varying delay systems. It has addressed conditions of failure for the system to remain exponentially stable. The problem is first described as the problem of exponential stability for one kind of switched delay systems. Then, two Lemmas reflecting the change properties of two special Lyapunov functional candidates for normal delay systems have been developed. Subsequently, it has been shown that under the constraint of the unavailability rate and the controller failure frequency, the whole delay system can be exponentially stable with a certain decay degree. Based on the piecewise Lyapunov functional method, explicit conditions have been given in the form of LMIs. An example of NCSs was given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
